quoteFirst: He picked it all to pieces, and turned the ruin over and over under his glass; and then he said there appeared to be something the matter with the hair-trigger.  He fixed it, and gave it a fresh start.  It did well now, except that always at
quoteLast: the hands would shut together like a pair of scissors, and from that time forth they would travel together.  The oldest man in the world could not make head or tail of the time of day by such a watch, and so I went again to have the thing repaired.
title: Sketches New and Old, Part 1.
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910

title:

quoteFirst: Its light didn't penetrate very far into the dense foliage, but it did enable us to make out the top of the mountain, which took the form of a vine covered outcrop of lava. We altered our course slightly, and at
quoteLast: the forest fell away and we faced a rough wall of rock some two hundred feet in height.
title: The Image and the Likeness
author: Campbell, John Scott

quoteFirst: Apparently, however, the consul-general at Panama had not received the information embodied in the Associated Press bulletin, upon which the Assistant Secretary of State based his dispatch; for his answer was that there was no uprising, although the situation was critical, this answer being received at 8.15 P.M. Immediately afterward he sent another dispatch, which was received at
quoteLast: , saying that the uprising had occurred, and had been successful, with no bloodshed. The Colombian gunboat _Bogota_ next day began to shell the city of Panama, with the result of killing one Chinaman.
title: Presidential addresses and state papers, Volume 2 (of 7)
author: Roosevelt, Theodore, 1858-1919

quoteLast: --Now we just have a glimpse of the Light from the bridge, and as ‘All’s well,’ I will to my couch for the night. The winds are favoring those on the port side, having swung around to the northeast, giving a promise of the southeast trades for to-morrow; so good-night.
title:
The Life of Henry Bradley Plant
Founder and President of the Plant System of Railroads and Steamships and Also of the Southern Express Company
author: Smyth, G. Hutchinson (George Hutchinson), 1837-; Dickerman, George Sherwood, 1843-1937 [Contributor]

quoteFirst: The sun was very bright and warm when they left camp at
quoteLast: , but a heavy fog hung like a curtain on the horizon, and shut out the land all around. They were, in fact, traveling on the Polar Sea, out of sight of land.
title:
Farthest North

quoteFirst: "If I do not come to you by
quoteLast: , or you are not sent for by then, you are all to leave any ante-room you may be in, and you are to walk straight up the central staircase, taking notice of nobody.  If they try to stop you, merely say you wish to see the Ambassador."
title: Mrs. Fitz
author: Snaith, J. C. (John Collis), 1876-1936

quoteLast: . Robard may come sooner than expected. I must hurry."

quoteFirst: “The carriage will be at the door at
quoteLast: , to take you to Waterloo,” he said, shouting. “You’ll have your things packed, and you’ll start--No, don’t leave the room.
title: Spinster of This Parish

quoteFirst: "Even that, if it were necessary to get the pearl, madame," said Cleek, with the utmost sang-froid. "Faugh!" looking at his watch, "a good twenty minutes wasted by the zealousness of those idiotic searchers of yours.
quoteLast: ! Just time for one brief song. Let us make hay while the sun lasts, madame, for it goes down suddenly in Mauravania; and for some of us--it never comes up again!" Then, throwing himself upon the piano-seat, he ran his fingers across the keys and broke into the stately measures of the national anthem.
title: Cleek: the Man of the Forty Faces
author: Hanshew, Thomas W., 1857-1914

quoteLast: . He would be very late. It was practically dark, though these bright days were endless. He wondered whether the children were in bed. It was too late, however, to wonder.
title: The Trespasser
author: Lawrence, D. H. (David Herbert), 1885-1930
